title: Things 3 vs Apple Reminders for Students
meta_description: Things 3 vs Apple Reminders for students who need short-term academic task tracking without learning a new productivity system.
constraint_lens: You need a task app just for school and exams that is quick to learn and easy to stop using later.

verdict.summary: Apple Reminders wins for students who only need academic task tracking for a term. You can create simple lists for each class and start immediately. Things 3 introduces projects, areas, and planning views that take time to understand. If learning the app takes longer than the term, Things fails first.
verdict.decision_rule: If learning the app takes longer than the term, Things fails first.

sections.heading: Why this matters for Students
sections.content: You said you need tasks only for school and exams. As a student, you want something you can set up quickly and abandon after the semester ends. Spending time learning a system reduces the benefit of a short term tool.

bullets.point: Structured system with Areas, Projects, and headings
bullets.why_it_matters: You can organize subjects deeply, but understanding how Areas differ from Projects takes time.

bullets.point: Today and Upcoming views tied to scheduled tasks
bullets.why_it_matters: You see deadlines clearly, yet learning how scheduling interacts with projects adds a small learning curve.

bullets.point: Clean interface designed around long term planning
bullets.why_it_matters: It supports ongoing productivity, but that depth may exceed a single term need.

bullets.point: Simple lists that can be named after each class
bullets.why_it_matters: You can create a list per subject without understanding project structures.

bullets.point: Quick task entry with optional due dates
bullets.why_it_matters: You can add assignments in seconds without navigating planning views.

bullets.point: No required system to maintain after exams
bullets.why_it_matters: You can delete or ignore lists once the term ends with no cleanup process.

sections.heading: Where each tool can break down

items.fails_when: You spend time understanding Areas and Projects instead of simply listing assignments.
items.what_to_do_instead: Use Apple Reminders if you want immediate academic tracking.

items.fails_when: You need more structured long term planning across multiple life areas.
items.what_to_do_instead: Use Things 3 if your academic work extends into ongoing personal systems.

sections.heading: When this verdict might flip
sections.content: If you plan to continue using the app beyond school and want a structured system for long term projects, Things 3 may justify its learning curve.

sections.heading: Quick decision rules
rules: If you need quick setup for one semester, choose Apple Reminders.
If learning a system feels like extra work, avoid Things 3.
If you want a long term productivity structure, Things 3 may fit better.

faqs.a: It is clean but introduces concepts like Areas and Projects that require a short learning period.

faqs.q: Can Apple Reminders handle exam deadlines?
faqs.a: Yes, you can set due dates and reminders for exams and assignments easily.

faqs.q: Which app is easier to stop using after school?
faqs.a: Apple Reminders is easier to abandon because it does not require maintaining a structured system.

faqs.q: Does Things 3 support academic projects well?
faqs.a: Yes, it supports structured projects, but that depth may exceed short term academic needs.
